sen.j: 許波多神社（こはたじんじゃ）は、京都府宇治市にある神社である。
sen.e: The Kohata-jinja Shrines are Shinto shrines located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.
The Kohata-jinja Shrines are Shinto shrines located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.
The Kohata-jinja Shrines are Shinto shrines located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社（名神大社）「許波多神社」の比定社であるが、宇治市内には許波多神社という名前の神社が木幡と五ヶ庄の隣接する2つの地区にあり、それぞれ異なる社伝を伝える。
sen.e: They have been identified as the "Kohata-jinja Shrines" (Myojin Taisha) listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) but within Uji City there are shrines named Kohata-jinja Shrine in the two adjacent areas of Kohata and Gokasho, and these both have different histories.

They have been identified as the "Kohata-jinja Shrines" (Myojin Taisha) listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) but within Uji City there are shrines named Kohata-jinja Shrine in the two adjacent areas of Kohata and Gokasho, and these both have different histories.

They have been identified as the 'Kohata-jinja Shrines' (Myojin Taisha) listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) but within Uji City there are shrines named Kohata-jinja Shrine in the two adjacent areas of Kohata and Gokasho, and these both have different histories.

sen.j: 旧社格はどちらも郷社。
sen.e: The shrines were ranked as Gosha under the old shrine classification system.
The shrines were ranked as Gosha under the old shrine classification system.
The shrines were ranked as Gosha (village shrine) under the old shrine classification system.

sen.j: 旧称柳大明神。
sen.e: They were both formerly named Yanagi Daimyojin Shrine.
They were both formerly named Yanagi Daimyojin Shrine.
They were both formerly named Yanagi Daimyojin Shrine.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では名神大社に列する。
sen.e: They are classified in the Engishiki Jinmyocho as a Myojin Taisha.
They are classified in the Engishiki Jinmyocho as a Myojin Taisha.
They are classified in the Engishiki Jinmyocho as a Myojin Taisha.

sen.j: 大海人皇子（後の天武天皇）や坂上田村麻呂が戦勝を祈願したと伝えられ、勝運を授かる神社として信仰されている。
sen.e: The shrines are said to be where Oama-no-Miko (later Emperor Tenmu) and SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro prayed for victory, and they are worshipped as shrines that bring good luck.
The shrines are said to be where Oama-no-Miko (later Emperor Tenmu) and SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro prayed for victory, and they are worshipped as shrines that bring good luck.
The shrines are said to be where Oama-no-Miko (later Emperor Tenmu) and SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro prayed for victory, and they are worshipped as shrines that bring good luck.

sen.j: どちらの許波多神社もアメノオシホミミが祭神に加えられている。
sen.e: Both Kohata-jinja Shrines enshrine Ameno Oshihomimi.
Both Kohata-jinja Shrines enshrine Ameno Oshihomimi.
Both Kohata-jinja Shrines enshrine Ameno Oshihomimi.

sen.j: 式内社で天忍穂耳命を祭神とする神社は許波多神社だけであることから、鎌倉時代の『釈日本紀』には「許波多神社に座す神は宗廟の神として、他と異にして尊崇すべきである」と記されている。
sen.e: As the only Engishiki-listed shrines to enshrine Ameno Oshihomimi are the Kohata-jinja Shrines, it is written in the Kamakura period "Shaku Nihongi" (an annotated text of the Nihon Shoki) that 'The kami at the Kohata-jinja Shrines are deities of ancestral mausoleums and should be revered in a manner that is different from others'.

As the only Engishiki-listed shrines to enshrine Ameno Oshihomimi are the Kohata-jinja Shrines, it is written in the Kamakura period "Shaku Nihongi" (an annotated text of the Nihon Shoki) that 'The kami at the Kohata-jinja Shrines are deities of ancestral mausoleums and should be revered in a manner that is different from others'.

As the only Engishiki-listed shrines to enshrine Ameno Oshihomimi are the Kohata-jinja Shrines, it is written in the Kamakura period "Shaku Nihongi" (an annotated text of the Nihon Shoki) that 'The kami at the Kohata-jinja Shrines are deities of ancestral mausoleums and should be revered in a manner that is different from others.'

sen.j: 永禄12年（1596年）には最高位の正一位の神階を受けた。
sen.e: In 1596, the deities were awarded the highest rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
In 1596, the deities were awarded the highest rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
In 1596, the deities were awarded the highest rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).

sen.j: 戦国時代、戦火により社殿のほとんどを焼失し、古伝も失われた。
sen.e: The shrine buildings were almost completely destroyed by fires arising from conflicts during the Warring States period and their ancient records were lost.
The shrine buildings were almost completely destroyed by fires arising from conflicts during the Warring States period and their ancient records were lost.
The shrine buildings were almost completely destroyed by fires arising from conflicts during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) and their ancient records were lost.

sen.j: 五ヶ庄の許波多神社
sen.e: Gokasho Kohata-jinja Shrine
Gokasho Kohata-jinja Shrine
Gokasho Kohata-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 天忍穂耳命のほかニニギ、神日本磐余彦尊（神武天皇）を祀る。
sen.e: In addition to Ameno Oshihomimi, the shrine also enshrines Ninigi and Kan Yamato Iwarehikono Mikoto (Emperor Jinmu).
In addition to Ameno Oshihomimi, the shrine also enshrines Ninigi and Kan Yamato Iwarehikono Mikoto (Emperor Jinmu).
In addition to Ameno Oshihomimi, the shrine also enshrines Ninigi and Kan Yamato Iwarehikono Mikoto (Emperor Jinmu).

sen.j: 社伝では、大化元年（645年）、蘇我倉山田石川麻呂の奏上により、孝徳天皇が中臣鎌足に命じて木幡荘に皇祖を祀る神殿を造営させたのに始まると伝えられる。
sen.e: According to a report made to the emperor by Soganokurano Yamadano ISHIKAWA no Maro in the year 645, Emperor Kotoku ordered NAKATOMI no Kamatari to build a shrine enshrining imperial ancestors at Kohata-so.

According to a report made to the emperor by Soganokurano Yamadano ISHIKAWA no Maro in the year 645, Emperor Kotoku ordered NAKATOMI no Kamatari to build a shrine enshrining imperial ancestors at Kohata-so.

According to a report made to the emperor by Soganokurano Yamadano ISHIKAWA no Maro in the year 645, the Emperor Kotoku ordered NAKATOMI no Kamatari to build a shrine enshrining imperial ancestors at Kohata-so.

sen.j: 当時は柳山の地に社殿があったことから「柳大明神」と呼ばれるようになり、江戸時代までは「柳神社」を正式の社名としていた。
sen.e: This shrine came to be known as "Yanagi Daimyojin Shrine" as it was located in Yanagiyama, and was formally named "Yanagi-jinja-shrine" until the Edo period.
This shrine came to be known as "Yanagi Daimyojin Shrine" as it was located in Yanagiyama, and was formally named "Yanagi-jinja-shrine" until the Edo period.
This shrine came to be known as 'Yanagi Daimyojin Shrine' as it was located in Yanagiyama, and was formally named 'Yanagi-jinja Shrine' until the Edo period.

sen.j: 明治時代、陸軍火薬庫の建設のため社地全体が官有地として召し上げられ、当社は御旅所であった旧岡田村内の現在地に遷座し、その際に社名を旧称の許波多神社に改称した。
sen.e: During the Meiji period, the entire shrine was commandeered by the state to serve as a gunpowder magazine; during which time the deities were transferred to the their current location in what was the building in which the sacred palanquin was stored in the former village of Okada and this was also the time when the shrine was renamed to its previous name of "Kohata-jinja Shrine".

During the Meiji period, the entire shrine was commandeered by the state to serve as a gunpowder magazine; during which time the deities were transferred to the their current location in what was the building in which the sacred palanquin was stored in the former village of Okada and this was also the time when the shrine was renamed to its previous name of "Kohata-jinja Shrine".

During the Meiji period, the entire shrine was commandeered by the state to serve as a gunpowder magazine; during which time the deities were transferred to the their current location in what was the building in which the sacred palanquin was stored in the former village of Okada and this was also the time when the shrine was renamed to its previous name of Kohata-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 平安時代後期の作とされる男女一対（馬頭天王・弁財天）の神像が伝わるが、これは附属の寺で祀られていたものである。
sen.e: The shrine has a pair of male and female god statues (Bato Tenno and Benzaiten) that are believed to date from the latter part of the Heian period but these are housed in the attached temple.
The shrine has a pair of male and female god statues (Bato Tenno and Benzaiten) that are believed to date from the latter part of the Heian period but these are housed in the attached temple.
The shrine has a pair of male and female god statues (Bato Tenno and Benzaiten) that are believed to date from the latter part of the Heian period but these are housed in the attached temple.

sen.j: 本殿には、鎌倉時代の作とされる天忍穂耳命の神像が祀られている。
sen.e: The main sanctuary is thought to have been constructed during the Kamakura period and enshrines a statue of Ameno Oshihomimi.
The main sanctuary is thought to have been constructed during the Kamakura period and enshrines a statue of Ameno Oshihomimi.
The main sanctuary is thought to have been constructed during the Kamakura period and enshrines a statue of Ameno Oshihomimi.

sen.j: かつて、社殿より続く東西2町の馬道で競馬（くらべうま）の神事が行われており、「競馬発祥の神社」とされている。
sen.e: A horseracing ritual used to be held on a bridle path that extends approximately 218m to the east and west of the shrine, and this shrine is believed to be "the birthplace of horseracing".
A horseracing ritual used to be held on a bridle path that extends approximately 218m to the east and west of the shrine, and this shrine is believed to be "the birthplace of horseracing".
A horseracing ritual used to be held on a bridle path that extends approximately 218 m to the east and west of the shrine, and this shrine is believed to be 'the birthplace of horseracing.'
sen.cmt: ハイフン挿入"→'ピリオド位置移動

sen.j: 当社に残る平安時代の鐙（あぶみ）は重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: The Heian period stirrups that remain at the shrine have been designated Important Cultural Properties.
The Heian period stirrups that remain at the shrine have been designated Important Cultural Properties.
The Heian period stirrups that remain at the shrine have been designated Important Cultural Properties.

sen.j: ほかにも、馬頭天王の神像があることから、「馬の神社」として競馬ファンや競馬関係者の信仰を集めている。
sen.e: The Bato Tenno statue has also led the shrine to become renowned as "Uma no Jinja" (lit. Horse Shrine) and draw many worshippers from among horseracing fans and those involved in the horseracing world.

The Bato Tenno statue has also led the shrine to become renowned as "Uma no Jinja" (lit. Horse Shrine) and draw many worshippers from among horseracing fans and those involved in the horseracing world.

The Bato Tenno statue has also led the shrine to become renowned as 'Uma no Jinja' (lit. Horse Shrine) and draw many worshippers from among horseracing fans and those involved in the horseracing world.

sen.j: 重要文化財
sen.e: Important Cultural Properties
Important Cultural Properties

sen.j: 本殿
sen.e: Main sanctuary
Main sanctuary

sen.j: 鉄宝相華孔雀銅象嵌半舌鐙（てつ ほうそうげくじゃく どうぞうがん はんじたあぶみ）一双、附鉄舌長鐙 一双
sen.e: A pair of iron half-tongue style stirrups with a copper-inlaid flower and peacock motif; designation also includes a pair of iron long-tongue style stirrups
A pair of iron half-tongue style stirrups with a copper-inlaid flower and peacock motif; designation also includes a pair of iron long-tongue style stirrups

sen.j: 男女神像 二体
sen.e: A pair of male and female god statues

sen.j: 木幡の許波多神社
sen.e: Kohata Kohata-jinja Shrine
Kohata Kohata-jinja Shrine
Kohata Kohata-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 社伝では、大化元年（645年）、皇極天皇が夢で「吾れ天神故に下土に神陵なし吾が霊を祭祀し給へ」とのお告げを受け、中臣鎌足に命じ木幡荘に社殿を造営させたと伝えられる。
sen.e: According to shrine legend, in the year 645 Emperor Kogyoku received a divine message in a dream saying "I am a sky god with no shrine on earth and I ask you to enshrine my spirit" and ordered NAKATOMI no Kamatari to build a shrine at Kohata-so.

According to shrine legend, in the year 645 Emperor Kogyoku received a divine message in a dream saying "I am a sky god with no shrine on earth and I ask you to enshrine my spirit" and ordered NAKATOMI no Kamatari to build a shrine at Kohata-so.

According to shrine legend, in the year 645 the Emperor Kogyoku received a divine message in a dream saying 'I am a sky god with no shrine on earth and I ask you to enshrine my spirit' and ordered NAKATOMI no Kamatari to build a shrine at Kohata-so.

sen.j: 壬申の乱を前に大海人皇子が大津宮から吉野に向かう際、社頭に柳の枝を挿して「我に天位を践まば、この柳、芽を出すべし」と戦勝を祈願した。
sen.e: When Oama-no-Miko departed Otsunomiya for Yoshino before the Jinshin Rebellion, he picked a branch from a willow tree in front of the shrine and prayed for victory; "May this branch bud if I come to ascend to the imperial throne".

When Oama-no-Miko departed Otsunomiya for Yoshino before the Jinshin Rebellion, he picked a branch from a willow tree in front of the shrine and prayed for victory; "May this branch bud if I come to ascend to the imperial throne".

When Oama-no-Miko departed Otsunomiya for Yoshino before the Jinshin Rebellion, he picked a branch from a willow tree in front of the shrine and prayed for victory; 'May this branch bud if I come to ascend to the imperial throne.'

sen.j: 大海人皇子が即位すると柳の枝が芽を出したことから、天皇は霊験を賛えて「柳大明神」の名を贈り、社領を寄進したという。
sen.e: When Oama-no-Miko ascended to the throne, the willow branch budded and the emperor praised the miracle by granting the shrine the name "Yanagi Daimyojin" and donating land.
When Oama-no-Miko ascended to the throne, the willow branch budded and the emperor praised the miracle by granting the shrine the name "Yanagi Daimyojin" and donating land.
When Oama-no-Miko ascended to the throne, the willow branch budded and the emperor praised the miracle by granting the shrine the name "Yanagi Daimyojin" and donating land.

sen.j: 明治41年（1908年）に旧河原村の田中神社を合祀したため、同社の祭神であった天照大神、天津彦根命も祭神としている。
sen.e: The shrine has also enshrined Amaterasu Omikami and Amatsu Hikone no Mikoto since 1908 when the deities of Tanaka-jinja Shrine in the former village of Kawahara were enshrined together with the existing deities.

The shrine has also enshrined Amaterasu Omikami and Amatsu Hikone no Mikoto since 1908 when the deities of Tanaka-jinja Shrine in the former village of Kawahara were enshrined together with the existing deities.

The shrine has also enshrined Amaterasu Omikami and Amatsu Hikone no Mikoto since 1908 when the deities of Tanaka-jinja Shrine in the former village of Kawahara were enshrined together with the existing deities.

sen.j: 境内には「狐塚」と呼ばれる宇治陵第36号墳墓があり、藤原基経の墓と伝えられている。
sen.e: The shrine precinct contains tomb no. 36 of the Uji mausoleum which is known as "Kitzunezuka" and said to be the burial place of FUJIWARA no Mototsune.
The shrine precinct contains tomb no. 36 of the Uji mausoleum which is known as "Kitzunezuka" and said to be the burial place of FUJIWARA no Mototsune.
